elements.content: Two metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with 3D structures, {[Co24(BDPO)12(H2O)12]·18DMF·40H2O} n (1) and {[NH2(CH3)2]4[Zn3(HBDPO)2(SO4)2]} n (2), were successfully synthesized based on CoII and ZnII inorganic nodes with the same bridging organic ligand (H4BDPO). Compound 1 possesses a relatively high BET surface area (∼1014 m2 g–1) with multiple pore systems and basic catalytic centers to be applied as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst. The resultant 2 exhibits a 3D structure based on Zn­(COO)4 and Zn2(SO4)2(COO)2 as inorganic secondary building units. Thanks to its luminescence property, 2 is able to be considered as a platform for a recyclable biresponsive luminescence sensor for explosives and antibiotics via luminescence quenching effect. The high selectivity of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol can be estimated by the K sv value of ∼1.2 × 104 M–1. Significantly, 2 can efficiently detect nitrofurantoin and nitrofurazone, and the corresponding K sv values are 4.5 × 104 and 4.9 × 104 M–1, respectively.

elements.content: Two 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) were successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Co-MOF exhibited a highly catalytis effect for Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Meanwhile, Zn-MOF can serve as a fast, recyclable, and multiresponsive luminescence sensor toward 2,4,6-trinitrophenol, nitrofurantoin, and nitrofurazone.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are fascinating crystal materials and that have captured the public’s attention because of their designability, porosity, and multiformity. They exhibit various potential applications in gas sorption and separation, catalysis, enzyme carrier, optical material, and so on. Notably, MOFs can be easily constructed by organic ligands and inorganic metals in the assembly, which both significantly influence the properties of MOFs. Functional groups can be introduced to the organic ligands to synthesize functional materials for targeted applications. In addition, different metal ions can remarkably change the structure and property of MOFs, including luminescence, catalysis, and so forth. MOFs have been widely investigated as heterogeneous catalysts in catalysis fields. Some MOFs based on organic ligands with nitrogen atoms have been investigated for their basic catalytic performance. Triazine ring fragments are always imported in ligands as central parts for constructing such basic MOF catalysts. Nevertheless, there is a significant demand for studying and developing such MOFs to catalyze organic reactions. In addition, luminescent MOFs possess various advantages, including distinct luminescence spectrum, visible color, simple operation, and high selectivity and sensitivity. Therefore, luminescence MOFs become the greatest potential sensor materials toward pollutants, such as explosives and heavy metals. Many luminescence MOFs have been widely applied as luminescence sensors to detect heavy metal ions, nitroaromatic compounds (NACs), organic vapors, and so forth. Notably, antibiotics are very useful and have a variety of benefits in many fields; however, they produce a sequence of concurrent problems. The residual antibiotics can be found in agricultural products, food, and rivers, prompting concerns about the transmission of antibiotic resistance through the food chain in human society. Only a few investigations have been reported to detect antibiotics by using luminescence MOFs. Hence, thus spurred further sustained attention toward explore novel sensing MOF materials for efficiently detecting antibiotics.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are fascinating crystal materials and that have captured the public's attention because of their designability, porosity, and multiformity. They exhibit various potential applications in gas sorption and separation, catalysis, enzyme carrier, optical material, and so on. Notably, MOFs can be easily constructed by organic ligands and inorganic metals in the assembly, which both significantly influence the properties of MOFs. Functional groups can be introduced to the organic ligands to synthesize functional materials for targeted applications. In addition, different metal ions can remarkably change the structure and property of MOFs, including luminescence, catalysis, and so forth. MOFs have been widely investigated as heterogeneous catalysts in catalysis fields. Some MOFs based on organic ligands with nitrogen atoms have been investigated for their basic catalytic performance. Triazine ring fragments are always imported in ligands as central parts for constructing such basic MOF catalysts. Nevertheless, there is a significant demand for studying and developing such MOFs to catalyze organic reactions. In addition, luminescent MOFs possess various advantages, including distinct luminescence spectrum, visible color, simple operation, and high selectivity and sensitivity. Therefore, luminescence MOFs become the greatest potential sensor materials toward pollutants, such as explosives and heavy metals. Many luminescence MOFs have been widely applied as luminescence sensors to detect heavy metal ions, nitroaromatic compounds (NACs), organic vapors, and so forth. Notably, antibiotics are very useful and have a variety of benefits in many fields; however, they produce a sequence of concurrent problems. The residual antibiotics can be found in agricultural products, food, and rivers, prompting concerns about the transmission of antibiotic resistance through the food chain in human society. Only a few investigations have been reported to detect antibiotics by using luminescence MOFs. Hence, thus spurred further sustained attention toward explore novel sensing MOF materials for efficiently detecting antibiotics.

elements.content: Herein, we first prepared two MOFs with 3D structures, {Co24(BDPO)12(H2O)12]·18DMF·40H2O} n (1) and {[NH2(CH3)2]4[Zn3(HBDPO)2(SO4)2]} n (2) (H4BDPO = 2,4-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenylamino)-6-ol triazine) based on CoII and ZnII metal nodes, respectively. The cobalt ion comes from Co­(NO3)2·6H2O; thus, the valence of cobalt ion should be +2. In addition, the whole neutral structure contains Co24(BDPO)12, and the value of BDPO is −4, which also confirms that the valence of cobalt ion is +2 in MOF 1.

The cobalt ion comes from Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O; thus, the valence of cobalt ion should be +2. In addition, the whole neutral structure contains Co24(BDPO)12, and the value of BDPO is -4, which also confirms that the valence of cobalt ion is +2 in MOF 1.

elements.content: As we discussed above, because of the different metal ions of CoII and ZnII, the resultant samples displayed completely different structures and properties. Compound 1 displayed excellent basic catalysis ability because of its high surface area with multiple pores and various Lewis basic sites. On the other hand, 2 was constructed by the organic ligand and two different Zn­(COO)4 and Zn2(SO4)2(COO)2 inorganic clusters. Compared with CoII-MOFs, the luminescence properties of the organic ligand can be well preserved in ZnII-MOFs. Hence, 2 exhibited similar luminescence properties like the free organic ligand H4BDPO; thus, it is considered as luminescence sensing for explosives and antibiotics.

Compared with CoII-MOFs, the luminescence properties of the organic ligand can be well preserved in ZnII-MOFs. Hence, 2 exhibited similar luminescence properties like the free organic ligand H4BDPO; thus, it is considered as luminescence sensing for explosives and antibiotics.

elements.content: All chemicals without any treatment were directly acquired from companies. The selected organic ligand H4BDPO was prepared as reported previously in the literature. The data of elemental analysis for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were collected on a CE-440 (Leeman Laboratories) analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) trials were executed on a DTG-60A (Shimadzu) instrument in air from 30 to 800 °C (10 °C min–1). Fourier-transform (FT) infrared spectra, using KBr as pellets, were acquired on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer. A Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer was used to obtain the UV–vis results. A Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer was applied for luminescence measurements. The N2, CO2 and CH4 sorption measurements were acquired on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 machine. Gas chromatography for the catalysis results were collected from Agilent 7890A.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals without any treatment were directly acquired from companies. The selected organic ligand H4BDPO was prepared as reported previously in the literature. The data of elemental analysis for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were collected on a CE-440 (Leeman Laboratories) analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) trials were executed on a DTG-60A (Shimadzu) instrument in air from 30 to 800 °C (10 °C min-1). Fourier-transform (FT) infrared spectra, using KBr as pellets, were acquired on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer. A Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer was used to obtain the UV-vis results. A Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer was applied for luminescence measurements. The N2, CO2 and CH4 sorption measurements were acquired on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 machine. Gas chromatography for the catalysis results were collected from Agilent 7890A.

elements.content: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.035 g) and H4BDPO (0.02g) were both directly dissolved in a DMF/H2O (5/0.5 mL) mixed solution in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Another 0.5 mL of HNO3 was further added to the solution. The autoclave was sealed well and heated at 135 °C. The purple block crystals were directly collected after 4 days (63% yield based on H4BDPO). Element analysis of C, N, and H for 1 (C282H338O178N78Co24). Calcd (%) C, 37.28; N, 12.03; H, 3.72. elements.content: ZnSO4·7H2O (0.03 g) and H4BDPO (0.02 g) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and EtOH (0.5 mL). The solution was added to HNO3 solution (0.6 mL, 2.0 mol L–1) and then was sealed into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave for 3 days at 120 °C in an oven to generate colorless pale crystals. The resultant sample can be collected by simply filtering and washed by fresh DMF several times. The crystal yield is ∼59% on account of the ligand. elements.content: Compound 1 was soaked in toluene as reactive solvent for 1 day before using it as a catalyst. Then, it was filtered and directly dried in air. Substrate (0.001 mol) and malononitrile (0.0011 mol) were both added to a glass reactor with 5 mL of toluene. When the reaction temperature reached 80 °C, 1 (0.1 g) was introduced into the reaction system and stirred under this reaction condition. The GC instrument was employed to analyze the yields.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for Catalysis Experiments

Compound 1 was soaked in toluene as reactive solvent for 1 day before using it as a catalyst. Then, it was filtered and directly dried in air. Substrate (0.001 mol) and malononitrile (0.0011 mol) were both added to a glass reactor with 5 mL of toluene. When the reaction temperature reached 80 °C, 1 (0.1 g) was introduced into the reaction system and stirred under this reaction condition. The GC instrument was employed to analyze the yields.

elements.content:
The recyclability of 1 was easily recollected by centrifugation and washed by fresh toluene after the catalysis experiment. The recollected samples were reused as a base catalyst.

Luminescence Sensing Experiments

The powder sample of 2 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF containing different nitro compounds (0.01 mol L–1) or antibiotics (0.00005 mol L–1). The luminescence results were directly collected after 2 min.

Typical Procedure for Luminescence Titration Study

The powder sample of 2 was dispersed in DMF solution (3 mL, 0.1 mg mL–1) and placed in a quartz cell. The quenching experiments were performed by gradually adding analyte of NACs (0.001 mol L–1), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and nitrofurazone (NFZ) (0.001 mol L–1) DMF solution. The experiment was duplicated in parallel three times.

Recyclable Luminescence Experiments

The recyclability of 2 was explored in DMF solution. After the first quenching trial, 2 powder was recollected by centrifugation and washed with fresh DMF. The recovered crystals were collected and reused in the next quenching experiments.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 2 were both measured on Bruker SMART APEX II with Cu Kα graphite radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). Adsorption correction was performed by multiscan absorption corrections using the SADABS program. These two frameworks were determined by direct methods, which were further refined using the SHELXTL program. The anisotropical technology was used for all non-hydrogen atoms. The PLATON/SQUEEZE method was applied to delete the contributions from solvent molecules and counter cations. The solvent-free structures of 1 and 2 were obtained by the SQUEEZE routine. Crystal data of complex 1 and 2 are both listed in , and the characteristic bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Analysis

The structures of 1 and 2 were both measured on Bruker SMART APEX II with Cu Kα graphite radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). Adsorption correction was performed by multiscan absorption corrections using the SADABS program. These two frameworks were determined by direct methods, which were further refined using the SHELXTL program. The anisotropical technology was used for all non-hydrogen atoms. The PLATON/SQUEEZE method was applied to delete the contributions from solvent molecules and counter cations. The solvent-free structures of 1 and 2 were obtained by the SQUEEZE routine. Crystal data of complex 1 and 2 are both listed in , and the characteristic bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S1.

Compound 1 belongs to the cubic Im 3 m space group, which contains 1/4 Co1, 1/4 Co2, 1/4 coordinated oxygen atom, and 1/4 fully deprotonated BDPO4– organic ligand in the asymmetrical unit (Figure S3). As illustrated in , it contains a very standard and common paddle wheel motif to assemble with the carboxylic acid groups in the ligand. Interesting, one nitrogen atom from the organic ligand is further coordinated with one Co site in the paddle wheel motif. It can be found, after analysis in detail, that there are three different microporous cages in 1 with 14.9 Å for the largest cage, 12.1 Å for the medium cage, and 8.9 Å for the small one. All of the cages were further connected by the carboxylate acids and nitrogen atoms in the organic ligands to form a 3D structure. From the angle of topology, the obtained network is a 5-node topology with the point symbol [46·64]. The total accessible volume of 1 is ∼49.5% without the guest and coordinated solvents in the PLATON/VOID method. Because of its distorted solvents and the weak X-ray diffraction data, all solvents cannot be located accurately by the results of the single crystal. Thus, they only can be inferred by TGA and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of {Co24(BDPO)12(H2O)12]⋅18DMF⋅40H2O} n  (1)

Compound 1 belongs to the cubic Im 3 m space group, which contains 1/4 Co1, 1/4 Co2, 1/4 coordinated oxygen atom, and 1/4 fully deprotonated BDPO4- organic ligand in the asymmetrical unit (Figure S3). As illustrated in , it contains a very standard and common paddle wheel motif to assemble with the carboxylic acid groups in the ligand. Interesting, one nitrogen atom from the organic ligand is further coordinated with one Co site in the paddle wheel motif. It can be found, after analysis in detail, that there are three different microporous cages in 1 with 14.9 Å for the largest cage, 12.1 Å for the medium cage, and 8.9 Å for the small one. All of the cages were further connected by the carboxylate acids and nitrogen atoms in the organic ligands to form a 3D structure. From the angle of topology, the obtained network is a 5-node topology with the point symbol [46⋅64]. The total accessible volume of 1 is ~49.5% without the guest and coordinated solvents in the PLATON/VOID method. Because of its distorted solvents and the weak X-ray diffraction data, all solvents cannot be located accurately by the results of the single crystal. Thus, they only can be inferred by TGA and elemental analysis.

elements.content: MOF 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetrical unit of 2 has a half Zn1 cation, one Zn2 cation, one SO4 2– ion, and one HBDPO3– ligand (Figure S4). As shown in a, there are two different Zn­(COO)4 and Zn2(SO4)2(COO)2 clusters as secondary building units. Zn1 adopts distorted octahedron configuration by six-coordinated oxygen donors from two monodentate and two chelating carboxylate groups. Zn2 adopts distorted tetrahedral configuration by four-connected from four oxygen atoms from two different SO4 2– ions and one chelating carboxylate group (Zn-O, 1.9554–2.8075 Å). In addition, two different Zn2 ions were further connected by two shared SO4 2– ions to form a binuclear inorganic cluster (Zn-O, 1.9502–2.6768 Å). Hence, the SO4 2– ion plays a necessary role for the coordinated process between ZnII ions and ligands. The Zn···Zn distance in the binuclear inorganic cluster is 4.5098 Å. The partial deprotonated HBDPO3– only adopts one coordinated mode (μ3–η1: η1: η1: η1: η1, b) to connect with three different Zn­(II) ions. Meanwhile, the ligands can link with these two Zn clusters to form an interesting 3D construction (c). However, the solvents in 2 are also hard to directly confirm, which are further able to be determined from the results of elemental analysis, FT-IR, and TGA data.

MOF 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetrical unit of 2 has a half Zn1 cation, one Zn2 cation, one SO4 2- ion, and one HBDPO3- ligand (Figure S4). As shown in a, there are two different Zn(COO)4 and Zn2(SO4)2(COO)2 clusters as secondary building units. Zn1 adopts distorted octahedron configuration by six-coordinated oxygen donors from two monodentate and two chelating carboxylate groups. Zn2 adopts distorted tetrahedral configuration by four-connected from four oxygen atoms from two different SO4 2- ions and one chelating carboxylate group (Zn-O, 1.9554-2.8075 Å). In addition, two different Zn2 ions were further connected by two shared SO4 2- ions to form a binuclear inorganic cluster (Zn-O, 1.9502-2.6768 Å). Hence, the SO4 2- ion plays a necessary role for the coordinated process between ZnII ions and ligands. The Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance in the binuclear inorganic cluster is 4.5098 Å. The partial deprotonated HBDPO3- only adopts one coordinated mode (μ3-η1: η1: η1: η1: η1, b) to connect with three different Zn(II) ions. Meanwhile, the ligands can link with these two Zn clusters to form an interesting 3D construction (c). However, the solvents in 2 are also hard to directly confirm, which are further able to be determined from the results of elemental analysis, FT-IR, and TGA data.

elements.content: MOF 1 loses ∼24.68% weight before 240 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing coordinated and guest molecules (calcd 24.79%, Figure S5). As illustrated in Figure S6, the TGA data of 2 shows a 12.49% weight loss before 250 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing guest cations and molecules (calcd 12.74%). The phase purity of the experimental sample can be determined by PXRD patterns based on their characteristic diffraction peaks (Figures S7 and S8). The PXRD results demonstrated the purity of MOFs 1 and 2.

Thermal and Chemical Stability

MOF 1 loses ~24.68% weight before 240 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing coordinated and guest molecules (calcd 24.79%, Figure S5). As illustrated in Figure S6, the TGA data of 2 shows a 12.49% weight loss before 250 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing guest cations and molecules (calcd 12.74%). The phase purity of the experimental sample can be determined by PXRD patterns based on their characteristic diffraction peaks (Figures S7 and S8). The PXRD results demonstrated the purity of MOFs 1 and 2.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 both directly exchanged the high boiling point guest molecules with low boiling point CH2Cl2 for 2 days. These MOFs were heated at 100 °C under vacuum for 12 h. The N2 gas sorption measurement of activated 1 was implemented to verify the permanent pore character at 77 K. N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K featured a completely reversible type-I adsorption characteristic of microporous materials (). The BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated directly as 1014 and 1147 m2 g–1, respectively. The corresponding pore width distributions are 7.3, 11.8, and 14.8 Å through the DFT method. The structure of the activated sample can be retained well by the PXRD measurement (Figure S9). It also exhibits more excellent CO2 adsorption capacity than the adsorption amounts of CH4 at 273 and 298 K (Figure S10). However, activated 2 did not have any N2 sorption at 77 K (Figure S11), which is mainly attributed to complete framework collapse after the activation process. The reason can be confirmed by the PXRD pattern of activated 2 (Figure S12).

N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K featured a completely reversible type-I adsorption characteristic of microporous materials (). The BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated directly as 1014 and 1147 m2 g-1, respectively. The corresponding pore width distributions are 7.3, 11.8, and 14.8 Å through the DFT method. The structure of the activated sample can be retained well by the PXRD measurement (Figure S9). It also exhibits more excellent CO2 adsorption capacity than the adsorption amounts of CH4 at 273 and 298 K (Figure S10). elements.content: Because of the high BET surface area, multiple pore systems and many basic sites, 1 was further studied for its catalytic properties in the Knoevenagel condensation model reaction. Fresh sample was directly soaked in toluene for 1 day prior to this catalytic reaction. Substrates with different structures (0.001 mol) and malononitrile (0.0011 mol) were both added into a glass reactor with 5 mL of toluene. When the reaction temperature reached 80 °C, catalytic 1 (0.1 g) was instantly placed into the reaction solution and stirred at this temperature. The GC instrument was employed to analyze the yields. contains the yield results of all the reactions, including malononitrile and different aldehyde substrates with or without 1. As illustrated in entry 1 of , the final yield of 2-benzylidenemalononitrile is ∼97% after reaction for 3 h. The kinetic catalysis performance of benzaldehyde as substrate was chosen as a model to investigate the catalytic rate in detail, which illustrated that this reaction was almost completed within 3 h in the presence of 1 (a). Because the corresponding yield almost remained unchanged after filtering 1 at 40 min, MOF 1 is clearly necessary for this reaction. Meanwhile, no 2-benzylidenemalononitrile can be detected without catalytic 1 after 3 h in entry 2 and a. For the substrate effect to be investigated, several different substituted aldehyde reactants were used in the presence of 1 under similar conditions. The yields of the aldehyde substrates with the withdrawing groups (-F and -NO2) were both >99% (entries 3 and 4), whereas the yield significantly decreased to 87% for one electron donor OMe group (entry 5) and 80% for two OMe groups (entry 6).

Catalysis Properties

Because of the high BET surface area, multiple pore systems and many basic sites, 1 was further studied for its catalytic properties in the Knoevenagel condensation model reaction. Fresh sample was directly soaked in toluene for 1 day prior to this catalytic reaction. Substrates with different structures (0.001 mol) and malononitrile (0.0011 mol) were both added into a glass reactor with 5 mL of toluene. When the reaction temperature reached 80 °C, catalytic 1 (0.1 g) was instantly placed into the reaction solution and stirred at this temperature. The GC instrument was employed to analyze the yields.  contains the yield results of all the reactions, including malononitrile and different aldehyde substrates with or without 1. As illustrated in entry 1 of , the final yield of 2-benzylidenemalononitrile is ~97% after reaction for 3 h. The kinetic catalysis performance of benzaldehyde as substrate was chosen as a model to investigate the catalytic rate in detail, which illustrated that this reaction was almost completed within 3 h in the presence of 1 (a). Because the corresponding yield almost remained unchanged after filtering 1 at 40 min, MOF 1 is clearly necessary for this reaction. Meanwhile, no 2-benzylidenemalononitrile can be detected without catalytic 1 after 3 h in entry 2 and a. For the substrate effect to be investigated, several different substituted aldehyde reactants were used in the presence of 1 under similar conditions. The yields of the aldehyde substrates with the withdrawing groups (-F and -NO2) were both >99% (entries 3 and 4), whereas the yield significantly decreased to 87% for one electron donor OMe group (entry 5) and 80% for two OMe groups (entry 6).

elements.content: Furthermore, it is a significantly important issue to recycle the catalysis after reaction. MOF 1 was easily recollected and reused by centrifugation and washing with toluene. The catalytic effect of recycled 1 was basically no loss after reuse four times. As illustrated in Figure S13, the PXRD peaks suggested that the framework of recycled samples can kept very well. The results of FT-IR and TGA of recycled samples after further washing with fresh DMF are similar to the as-synthesized samples, which illustrates that the structure of recycled 1 was retained very well (Figures S14 and S15).

elements.content: The luminescence behaviors of the H4BDPO ligand and ground 2 were both investigated in detail. a shows the maximum emission of the free ligand at 382 nm under 337 nm. Compound 2 showed a significant emission peak at 379 nm under excitation wavelength at 292 nm (b), revealing that the luminescence property of 2 belongs to the organic ligand. For the luminescence detection capability toward NACs to be studied, the maximum emission peak of the ground samples in DMF with different detectable substances were collected under 292 nm (c). Significantly, remarkable luminescence quenching behavior was observed in nitrobenzene (NB) DMF solution. In addition, the luminescence intensity can be kept well in DMF for 1 day (Figure S16). For further detecting the luminescence response, resultant 2 was titrated with NB to vary the concentration (d). The corresponding luminescence intensity quickly reduced to 81 and 24% at 1 × 10–3 and 1 × 10–2 M, respectively, which may be ascribed to the electron transfer from the host structure of 2 to electron-deficient NB.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

The luminescence behaviors of the H4BDPO ligand and ground 2 were both investigated in detail. a shows the maximum emission of the free ligand at 382 nm under 337 nm. Compound 2 showed a significant emission peak at 379 nm under excitation wavelength at 292 nm (b), revealing that the luminescence property of 2 belongs to the organic ligand. For the luminescence detection capability toward NACs to be studied, the maximum emission peak of the ground samples in DMF with different detectable substances were collected under 292 nm (c). Significantly, remarkable luminescence quenching behavior was observed in nitrobenzene (NB) DMF solution. In addition, the luminescence intensity can be kept well in DMF for 1 day (Figure S16). For further detecting the luminescence response, resultant 2 was titrated with NB to vary the concentration (d). The corresponding luminescence intensity quickly reduced to 81 and 24% at 1 × 10-3 and 1 × 10-2 M, respectively, which may be ascribed to the electron transfer from the host structure of 2 to electron-deficient NB.

elements.content: Hence, the luminescence sensing ability of 2 was further discussed in detail to detect several typical NACs, including 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). The luminescence intensities were monitored with the different concentrations of the analytes in DMF solution (a–c), which were almost completely quenched at last. The quenching efficiency is able to be quantitatively determinated by the Stern–Volmer equation as I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q], in which I 0 is the initial intensity without any analyte, I is the intensity after treating with the analyte, [Q] is the molar concentration of substances (M–1), and K sv is the Stern–Volmer constant. When the (I 0/I) – 1 vs [Q] plot exhibits a linear relationship, the K sv value can be determined exactly. As shown in Figure S17, the Sterm–Volmer data for these NACs were all close to a linear relationship in the relatively low concentration range. The corresponding K sv values are 3.0 × 102, 9.8 × 102, 1.9 × 103, and 1.2 × 104 M–1 for NB, 1,3-DNB, 2,4-DNT, and TNP, respectively. The order of quenching efficiency is TNP > 2,4-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB due to the enhancement of the electron transfer from 2 to NACs with the increasing amount of nitro groups (d). Notably, the UV–vis result illustrated that the absorption band of TNP and emission spectrum of 2 have the most overlap area in DMF to significantly enhance the quenching effect (Figure S18). In addition, 2 was easily recollected by centrifuging at 8000 rpm for 3 min and washing with DMF. As demonstrated in Figure S19, the luminescence sensing ability of 2 shows very little change after reusing five times. Meanwhile, the structure can be kept well after the recycle experiment by the PXRD data (Figure S20).

elements.content: As is known, only a few luminescence MOFs have been used as sensors to detect different antibiotics. In this work, ten frequently used antibiotics were selected as models to investigate the antibiotics detectable ability of 2, including florfenicol (FFC), penicillin (PCL), thiamphenicol (THI), chloramphenicol (CAP), azithromycin (AZM), sulfamethazine (SMZ), ronidazole (RDZ), ornidazole (ODZ), nitrofurazone (NFZ), and nitrofurantoin (NFT). The luminescence data of 2 were detected in the presence of various antibiotics (FFC, PCL, THI, CAP, AZM, SMZ, RDZ, ODZ, NFZ, and NFT) in DMF, demonstrating a clear luminescence quenching phenomenon for NFZ or NFT, respectively (a). The quenching order of 2 toward these antibiotics is NFT > NFZ > ODZ > RDZ > SMZ > AZM > CAP > THI > PCL > FFC. The results obviously showed that 2 can be considered as a potential luminescence sensor to recognize NFZ or NFT via luminescence quenching. In addition, the luminescence response experiments of 2 toward NFZ were measured at different time intervals (b). After the concentration of NFZ (1.0 × 10–5 or 7.0 × 10–5 mol L–1), the luminescence intensities both immediately decreased and achieved a minimum value after ∼50 s. The intensity can be further kept for a long time to illustrate that the luminescence intensity can be completely quenched in a very short time.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Sensing of Antibiotics

As is known, only a few luminescence MOFs have been used as sensors to detect different antibiotics. In this work, ten frequently used antibiotics were selected as models to investigate the antibiotics detectable ability of 2, including florfenicol (FFC), penicillin (PCL), thiamphenicol (THI), chloramphenicol (CAP), azithromycin (AZM), sulfamethazine (SMZ), ronidazole (RDZ), ornidazole (ODZ), nitrofurazone (NFZ), and nitrofurantoin (NFT). The luminescence data of 2 were detected in the presence of various antibiotics (FFC, PCL, THI, CAP, AZM, SMZ, RDZ, ODZ, NFZ, and NFT) in DMF, demonstrating a clear luminescence quenching phenomenon for NFZ or NFT, respectively (a). The quenching order of 2 toward these antibiotics is NFT > NFZ > ODZ > RDZ > SMZ > AZM > CAP > THI > PCL > FFC. The results obviously showed that 2 can be considered as a potential luminescence sensor to recognize NFZ or NFT via luminescence quenching. In addition, the luminescence response experiments of 2 toward NFZ were measured at different time intervals (b). After the concentration of NFZ (1.0 × 10-5 or 7.0 × 10-5 mol L-1), the luminescence intensities both immediately decreased and achieved a minimum value after ~50 s. The intensity can be further kept for a long time to illustrate that the luminescence intensity can be completely quenched in a very short time.

elements.content: (a) Luminescence intensities of 2 in different antibiotic DMF solutions; (b) luminescence response rate of 2 in NFZ at different concentrations; (c, d) emission spectra of 2 after titrating with NFT or NFZ; (e, f) Stern–Volmer plots for the intensity of 2 with different concentrations of NFT or NFZ, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Luminescence intensities of 2 in different antibiotic DMF solutions; (b) luminescence response rate of 2 in NFZ at different concentrations; (c, d) emission spectra of 2 after titrating with NFT or NFZ; (e, f) Stern-Volmer plots for the intensity of 2 with different concentrations of NFT or NFZ, respectively.

elements.content: For further investigating the detection ability of 2 toward NFZ or NFT, the titration experiments were performed by adding NFZ or NFT drop by drop. With increasing concentration of NFZ or NFT, the corresponding luminescence intensity decreased obviously (c and d). Meanwhile, the corresponding quenching performance can be quantitatively determinated by the values of (I 0/I) – 1 vs the concentrations of NFZ or NFT. As shown in e and f, the K sv values for NFZ and NFT are calculated to be 4.5 × 104 and 4.9 × 104 M–1 with R 2 values of 0.9989 and 0.9993, respectively. Meanwhile, the recyclability is also a vitally important issue to detect NFZ or NFT. The reused samples were easily recollected and reused. The recycled crystals can perfectly preserve the luminescence properties like the fresh samples, which can be further used as a luminescence sensor to redetect NFZ or NFT at least five times (Figure S21). The integrity of the skeleton can be confirmed by PXRD patterns, which can retain the characteristic peak to prove the stability during the tests (Figure S20). It is significant work to investigate the luminescence quenching mechanism for NFZ and NFT with high selectivity of 2. The results illustrated that the quenching effect is not trigged by the broken skeleton. In addition, the quick test results of 2 demonstrated that the quenching effect is also not caused by guest molecule adsorption. Overlap between the absorption spectra of NFT or NFZ and the emission spectrum of 2 in DMF is easily observed from the UV–vis results (Figure S22), which illustrate that the excitation energy may be competitively absorbed by the NFZ or NFT molecules to obviously reduce the energy transfer to 2 to produce luminescence quenching phenomenon. All the luminescence data of 2 have been tabulated in Table S2.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully obtained two 3D MOFs. The different metal ions (CoII and ZnII) directly generate different structures and properties. Resultant 1 shows high catalysis effect for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction with outstanding recyclability. In addition, 2 exhibits excellent luminescence property to use as a fast, recyclable, and multi-responsive luminescence sensor toward TNP, NFZ, and NFT. Further work regarding novel and functional MOFs is ongoing in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully obtained two 3D MOFs. The different metal ions (CoII and ZnII) directly generate different structures and properties. Resultant 1 shows high catalysis effect for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction with outstanding recyclability. In addition, 2 exhibits  excellent luminescence property to use as a fast, recyclable, and multi-responsive luminescence sensor toward TNP, NFZ, and NFT. Further work regarding novel and functional MOFs is ongoing in our laboratory.

Synthesis of {Co24(BDPO)12(H2O)12]⋅18DMF⋅40H2O} n , 1 

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.035 g) and H4BDPO (0.02g) were both directly dissolved in a DMF/H2O (5/0.5 mL) mixed solution in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Another 0.5 mL of HNO3 was further added to the solution. The autoclave was sealed well and heated at 135 °C. The purple block crystals were directly collected after 4 days (63% yield based on H4BDPO). Element analysis of C, N, and H for 1 (C282H338O178N78Co24). Calcd (%) C, 37.28; N, 12.03; H, 3.72. Found: C, 37.33; N, 12.15; H, 3.79. IR (cm-1): 3341 (br), 2931 (s), 1644 (s), 1593 (s), 1557 (s), 1531 (s), 1434 (s), 1375 (s), 1149 (s), 1086 (s), 894 (s), 807 (s), 774 (s), 735 (s), 665 (s), 640 (s), 592 (s), 490 (s) (Figure S1).

Synthesis of {[NH2(CH3)2]4[Zn3(HBDPO)2(SO4)2]} n , 2 

ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.03 g) and H4BDPO (0.02 g) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (5 mL) and EtOH (0.5 mL). The solution was added to HNO3 solution (0.6 mL, 2.0 mol L-1) and then was sealed into a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave for 3 days at 120 °C in an oven to generate colorless pale crystals. The resultant sample can be collected by simply filtering and washed by fresh DMF several times. The crystal yield is ~59% on account of the ligand. Element analysis of C, N, and H for 2 (C46H52O26N14S2Zn3): Calcd (%) C, 37.42; N, 13.29; H, 3.53. Found: C, 37.59; N, 13.33; H, 3.52. IR (cm-1): 3134 (br), 2803 (s), 2482 (s), 1708 (s), 1647 (s), 1578 (s), 1560 (s), 1552 (s), 1467 (s), 1364 (s), 1273 (s), 1261 (s), 1234 (s), 1036 (s), 977 (s), 851 (s), 780 (s), 764 (s), 733 (s), 715 (s), 677 (s), 607 (s), 460 (s) (Figure S2).

cln_elements.content:
Two metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with 3D structures, {[Co24(BDPO)12(H2O)12]·18DMF·40H2O} n (1) and {[NH2(CH3)2]4[Zn3(HBDPO)2(SO4)2]} n (2), were successfully synthesized based on CoII and ZnII inorganic nodes with the same bridging organic ligand (H4BDPO). Compound 1 possesses a relatively high BET surface area (∼1014 m2 g–1) with multiple pore systems and basic catalytic centers to be applied as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst. The resultant 2 exhibits a 3D structure based on Zn­(COO)4 and Zn2(SO4)2(COO)2 as inorganic secondary building units. Thanks to its luminescence property, 2 is able to be considered as a platform for a recyclable biresponsive luminescence sensor for explosives and antibiotics via luminescence quenching effect. The high selectivity of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol can be estimated by the K sv value of ∼1.2 × 104 M–1. Significantly, 2 can efficiently detect nitrofurantoin and nitrofurazone, and the corresponding K sv values are 4.5 × 104 and 4.9 × 104 M–1, respectively.

Results and DiscussionStructure of {Co<sub>24</sub>(BDPO)<sub>12</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>12</sub>]·18DMF·40H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Compound 1 belongs to the cubic Im 3 m space group, which contains 1/4 Co1, 1/4 Co2, 1/4 coordinated oxygen atom, and 1/4 fully deprotonated BDPO4– organic ligand in the asymmetrical unit (Figure S3). As illustrated in , it contains a very standard and common paddle wheel motif to assemble with the carboxylic acid groups in the ligand. Interesting, one nitrogen atom from the organic ligand is further coordinated with one Co site in the paddle wheel motif. It can be found, after analysis in detail, that there are three different microporous cages in 1 with 14.9 Å for the largest cage, 12.1 Å for the medium cage, and 8.9 Å for the small one. All of the cages were further connected by the carboxylate acids and nitrogen atoms in the organic ligands to form a 3D structure. From the angle of topology, the obtained network is a 5-node topology with the point symbol [46·64]. The total accessible volume of 1 is ∼49.5% without the guest and coordinated solvents in the PLATON/VOID method. Because of its distorted solvents and the weak X-ray diffraction data, all solvents cannot be located accurately by the results of the single crystal. Thus, they only can be inferred by TGA and elemental analysis.

Thermal and Chemical Stability

MOF 1 loses ∼24.68% weight before 240 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing coordinated and guest molecules (calcd 24.79%, Figure S5). As illustrated in Figure S6, the TGA data of 2 shows a 12.49% weight loss before 250 °C, which is similar with the calculated result after removing guest cations and molecules (calcd 12.74%). The phase purity of the experimental sample can be determined by PXRD patterns based on their characteristic diffraction peaks (Figures S7 and S8). The PXRD results demonstrated the purity of MOFs 1 and 2.

Gas Sorption Properties

Compounds 1 and 2 both directly exchanged the high boiling point guest molecules with low boiling point CH2Cl2 for 2 days. These MOFs were heated at 100 °C under vacuum for 12 h. The N2 gas sorption measurement of activated 1 was implemented to verify the permanent pore character at 77 K. N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K featured a completely reversible type-I adsorption characteristic of microporous materials (). The BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated directly as 1014 and 1147 m2 g–1, respectively. The corresponding pore width distributions are 7.3, 11.8, and 14.8 Å through the DFT method. The structure of the activated sample can be retained well by the PXRD measurement (Figure S9). It also exhibits more excellent CO2 adsorption capacity than the adsorption amounts of CH4 at 273 and 298 K (Figure S10). However, activated 2 did not have any N2 sorption at 77 K (Figure S11), which is mainly attributed to complete framework collapse after the activation process. The reason can be confirmed by the PXRD pattern of activated 2 (Figure S12).

Luminescence Properties

The luminescence behaviors of the H4BDPO ligand and ground 2 were both investigated in detail. a shows the maximum emission of the free ligand at 382 nm under 337 nm. Compound 2 showed a significant emission peak at 379 nm under excitation wavelength at 292 nm (b), revealing that the luminescence property of 2 belongs to the organic ligand. For the luminescence detection capability toward NACs to be studied, the maximum emission peak of the ground samples in DMF with different detectable substances were collected under 292 nm (c). Significantly, remarkable luminescence quenching behavior was observed in nitrobenzene (NB) DMF solution. In addition, the luminescence intensity can be kept well in DMF for 1 day (Figure S16). For further detecting the luminescence response, resultant 2 was titrated with NB to vary the concentration (d). The corresponding luminescence intensity quickly reduced to 81 and 24% at 1 × 10–3 and 1 × 10–2 M, respectively, which may be ascribed to the electron transfer from the host structure of 2 to electron-deficient NB.

metadata.title:
Two 3D Metal–Organic Frameworks Based on CoII and ZnII Clusters for Knoevenagel Condensation
Reaction and Highly Selective Luminescence Sensing
